We’ve all been there. Standing at the edge of our comfort zone, heart pounding, your dreams so close. Maybe it’s that book you’ve always talked about writing, or the marathon you’ve been putting off, or that ticket to a far-off place with a name you can barely pronounce.
You can see it, feel it, almost taste it. But when it’s time to turn that vision into reality, something strange happens. We freeze. And our dreams? They stay just that - dreams.
It’s like there’s an invisible wall holding us back. Our minds start racing with excuses: “I’m too tired”, “I’m not ready”, “What if I fail?”
That energy that was pushing us forward? It fades away, leaving us stuck on the wrong side of action.
This invisible barrier is tricky. It doesn’t show up with flashing lights or loud alarms. Instead, it whispers doubts, fills our heads with reasons to wait, to hold back, to stay cozy in our comfort zone.
But here’s the thing: this barrier, as solid as it feels, is actually as fragile as a soap bubble. All it takes is one bold move to pop it. Yet for many of us, that single step feels as hard as moving a mountain.
So how do we break through? How do we cross the gap between our big dreams and the actions we need to take?
The answer is in building something powerful enough to smash any barrier: a sense of urgency. As Elinor Smith once said:
“Successful people rarely sit back and let things happen. They go out and make things happen.”
The Burning Ships Strategy: A Lesson from History It’s the 3rd century BC, and the Persian coast is alive with activity. Many ships from Macedonia have just landed, their bottoms scratching the sand as they reach shore. Leading this attack is Alexander the Great, looking out for signs of the enemy.
But something is amiss. As reports filter in, a hard truth becomes clear: the Persian army outnumbers the Macedonians five to one. The odds are staggering. Winning battles is hard enough, but winning against an army five times your size? It seems impossible.
In the Macedonian camp, soldiers are worried. They look at each other with fear, speaking quietly about their small chance of winning. Military leaders throughout history know a simple truth: when morale is low, defeat is almost certain.
But Alexander is not just any leader. In this moment of crisis, he conceives a strategy so audacious it will echo through the ages.
“Burn all our ships,” he commands, his voice steady and resolute.
His officers stare in disbelief. Surely they’ve misheard. But no - Alexander repeats the order, his eyes shining with determination.
As flames engulf their means of retreat, the soldiers’ minds race. They had been contemplating their dire situation, wondering if it might be wiser to turn back, to live and fight another day. Now, that option has literally gone up in smoke.
In this moment, Alexander channels the wisdom of Sun Tzu, the legendary Chinese philosopher who would write in “The Art of War”:
“Bring the troops to a point where they have no way out, so that they must die before they can escape. If they are in grave danger, they will lose their fear. If they have nowhere to go, they will stand firm. If they have no choice, they will fight.”
The message of the burning ships is clear and terrifying at the same time: there is no going back. It’s victory or death.
This drastic action ignites something in the Macedonian army. The sense of urgency is palpable, electric. It courses through the ranks, transforming fear and doubt into fierce determination. With retreat no longer an option, they turn to face the enemy, their resolve hardened by the knowledge that everything hinges on this moment.
As they charge into battle, the impossible becomes possible. Against all odds, the Macedonians emerge victorious.
But Alexander’s triumph that day goes beyond the battlefield. By creating a situation of extreme urgency, he unlocks the full potential of his army. He proves a timeless truth: comfort breeds complacency, but urgency breeds greatness.
In the fires of those burning ships, Alexander forges more than just a military victory. He creates a lesson that will resonate through the centuries - a testament to the power of urgency in overcoming seemingly insurmountable odds.
Steve Jobs and the Power of Urgency: Echoes of Alexander’s Strategy The clock ticks relentlessly. One week until the launch of the first Macintosh. The air in the room is thick with tension as the engineering team approaches Steve Jobs, their faces etched with worry.
“It’s impossible we can make it in one week,” they plead, voices tinged with exhaustion. “We need one more week.”
Jobs stands before them, silent for a moment. His eyes scan the room, taking in the faces of his team. Then, channeling the spirit of Alexander the Great, he delivers his verdict:
“If you can do it in two weeks, you can do it in one”, Steve says.
The room falls silent. Engineers exchange worried glances, the weight of Jobs’ words settling on their shoulders. They know what this means - sleepless nights, skipped meals, a mad sprint to the finish line.
But Jobs isn’t finished. He fixes each team member with a piercing stare, his voice low and intense. “We’re not just launching a computer,” he says. “We’re starting a revolution. And revolutions wait for no one.”
In that moment, Jobs has done more than refuse a delay. He has created a crucible, a pressure cooker that will either forge his team into innovators capable of changing the world - or break them entirely.
Jobs understood a fundamental truth: to make a revolution in personal computers, intelligence alone is not enough. You need:
Resilience. Grit. A willingness to work incredibly hard. A team brave and determined enough to challenge the status quo. This approach wasn’t born from cruelty or unreasonableness. Jobs believed that many of our first impressions are often based on fear - fear of failure, fear of not meeting expectations, fear of innovating and falling short. And fear, he knew, is the great enemy of action and change.
In pushing his team to the limit, Jobs wasn’t just trying to meet a deadline. He was unlocking his team’s full potential, forcing them to confront their fears and overcome them. He understood that true innovation doesn’t happen in comfort zones - it happens when your back is against the wall and there’s no choice but to push forward.
A week later, the unthinkable happened. The engineers, driven by the sense of urgency Jobs had instilled in them, met the original deadline. The presentation was a success, marking the beginning of a new era in personal computing.
This story illustrates a powerful lesson: sometimes, the limitations we perceive are just that - perceptions. When pushed, when inspired, when filled with a sense of urgency and purpose, we are capable of far more than we imagine.
In the end, Jobs’ strategy wasn’t about bullying or unreasonable demands. It was about creating an environment where innovation could thrive, where ordinary people could achieve extraordinary things. It was about understanding that revolutions - whether in technology, business, or society - are built on the foundation of urgency, determination, and the courage to push beyond perceived limits.
The Urgency Principle: Elon Musk’s Relentless Drive In the high-stakes world of aerospace innovation, a tense scene unfolded between Elon Musk and Tom Mueller, head of SpaceX’s Merlin engine team. Mueller had just presented an aggressive timeline for completing a prototype, but Musk, ever the visionary, was far from satisfied.
“Cut it in half,” Musk demanded, his eyes locked on Mueller.
Incredulous, Mueller protested. “Such an aggressive schedule can’t be reduced any further,” he argued, his voice tinged with disbelief.
But Musk, unwavering in his conviction, refused to back down. “A manic sense of urgency is our operating principle,” he declared. It was clear that in Musk’s view, they weren’t acting with enough of it.
The ultimatum came swiftly and decisively. Musk stared Mueller in the face and delivered his final word: if Mueller wanted to keep his job as head of the engine team, he had to find a way to shorten the timeline. Faced with this stark choice, Mueller agreed.
What followed was a period of intense work and relentless effort. The team pushed themselves to the limit, striving to meet Musk’s seemingly impossible deadline. As the dust settled and the engine prototype was completed, a surprising truth emerged: Mueller had been right. The schedule Musk had imposed was indeed too aggressive.
But this raises a crucial question: Does this mean that a sense of urgency is unhelpful? Far from it.
The secret to SpaceX’s ability to revolutionize the aerospace industry lies in a powerful combination: first principles thinking coupled with an insane sense of urgency. This approach, while challenging, has made all the difference in the long run.
Mueller’s later reflection paints a vivid picture of this paradox:
“Even though we didn’t meet most of the schedules and cost targets that Elon had set, we outperformed all of our competitors. We were developing the most amazing rockets at the lowest cost in history, and we felt great about it in the end, even if Elon wasn’t happy with us.”
The Ultimate Urgency: Dostoyevsky’s Awakening St. Petersburg, 1849. A cold December morning. Fyodor Dostoyevsky, shackled and disoriented, is led into a square teeming with soldiers and onlookers. The air is thick with tension and the bitter Russian winter.
One year before, Dostoyevsky was arrested and imprisoned for the supposed involvement in a conspiracy against the russian tsar. The punishment: jail for a given period of time. But, one day, the tsar changed his plans.
On that square, Dostoyevsky suddenly noticed something. A scaffold, a priest, and coffins. His coffin. Time seems to stop as the reality sinks in: he’s about to die.
In that moment, facing his own mortality, Dostoyevsky’s life flashes before his eyes. Not in a blur of memories, but in stark clarity of wasted opportunities and unfulfilled potential.
But fate had other plans. Just as the executioner raises his hand, a messenger arrives, breathless. The Tsar has commuted the sentence - life instead of death, Siberian labor instead of the noose.
In the echoing silence of his reprieve, Dostoyevsky has an epiphany. He writes to his brother:
“When I look back on the past and think how much time I wasted in vain, how much of it was lost in illusions, in mistakes, in idleness, in the inability to live, how I did not value it, […] then my heart shrinks with sorrow. Life is a gift, life is happiness, every moment could have been an eternity of happiness”
As Confucius wisely noted:
“We have two lives: the second begins when we realize we have only one.”
Your Turn: Embracing Urgency in Everyday Life Here’s the thing: you don’t need to face execution or launch a revolutionary product to tap into the power of urgency. The secret? Create your own sense of urgency. Light your own fire.
Remember: inaction has a cost. So, let’s start small:
Pick one goal or project you’ve been putting off Set an unrealistic deadline for it. Yes, unrealistic Tell someone about your deadline. Make yourself accountable Attack it with a manic sense of urgency Watch what happens Will you hit your ambitious target? Maybe not. But you’ll likely achieve more than you would have otherwise. This little experiment can help you shatter those self-imposed limits and uncover reserves of energy and creativity you never knew you had.
Living with urgency means truly grasping that your time is limited. We all know this in our heads, but how often do we live it? If you carry the idea that one day it will all end, you’ll likely squeeze more life out of every moment.
In our fast-paced world, the most urgent thing we can do is stop waiting and start becoming. Your dreams, your goals, your life - they’re all waiting for you to take that leap.
Don’t wait for:
Someone to push you with extreme deadlines A near-death experience to start living The perfect moment Embrace urgency today.
After all, the clock is ticking for all of us - how will you make your moments count?
The choice, and the urgency, is yours.

“Ideas are like fish. If you want to catch small fish, you can stay in the shallow water. But if you want to catch the big fish, you have to go deeper. In the deep, the fish are more powerful and pure. They are giant and abstract. And they are very beautiful. ~David Lynch
The goals we set for ourselves are like fish. Do we choose a small fish or a big one? It’s easiest to aim for small fish, but I think we should all aim for bigger fish.
We should all aim high. Higher than what we first think is reasonable. And there are several reasons why.
We do it because it is hard In September 1962, President John F. Kennedy gave a speech at Rice University in which he promised to put a man on the moon and return him safely before the end of the decade.
Many of the technological requirements for going to the moon had not yet been developed. Kennedy himself mentioned in his speech that the rocket that would carry astronauts to the Moon would be “made of new metal alloys, some not yet invented, capable of withstanding heat and stress many times greater than has ever been experienced, all assembled with a precision better than the best watch” and sent “on an untried mission to an unknown celestial body”.
This was an extremely ambitious goal. Not only was it doubtful whether the United States would be able to put a man on the moon, but also why. What was the reason for such a complicated goal? Kennedy himself answered in his speech: “We choose to go to the moon in this decade, and to do the other things, not because they are easy, but because they are hard.
We’re not doing it because it’s easy. We do it because it’s hard. Because if we choose to do hard things, we may fail, yes, but we will have more opportunities to improve. We need to set ambitious goals because our goals determine how far you can go. If we set a small goal, bigger goals are automatically out of reach.
As James Cameron said, “If you set your goals ridiculously high and it’s a failure, you’re going to fail on top of everyone else’s success”.
Your transformation as a person Imagine you have never run before and you decide to set yourself the goal of running your first half marathon within 6 months. But because you like to aim high, you don’t just want to run a half marathon, you want to run a marathon. That’s your goal.
There is a big gap between not running and finishing a half marathon. But there is a huge gap between not running and finishing a marathon. Before you start, you should know that if you aim so high, you will most likely fail. It’s that simple. It’s also almost certain that many people will try to persuade you to set a more conservative goal, such as just running the half marathon. Or even not to run the half-marathon at all, but just to run occasionally. Should you listen to them? Yes, but I don’t think they’re right.
If you’re satisfied with running a half, you’re not doing enough to finish the marathon. Arnold Schwarzenegger said, “If I’m satisfied with being Mr Austria, I’m not doing enough to be Mr Olympia”. I’m not saying that running a half marathon is worthless (of course it is not).
But I think that what is really important is not finishing a half or a marathon, but your personal transformation in the pursuit of that goal. And the greater the challenge you set for yourself, the greater your opportunity to improve as a person.
If you decide to run the marathon, you’re going to have to work that much harder. You’ll need to be in better physical shape, which means exercising more, eating healthier and prioritizing your rest even more. And to achieve all this, you will need to be more disciplined, have more self-control, know how to deal with the self-imposed pressure of your aggressive goal, and much more.
If you really think about it, whether you achieve your goal or not is a fleeting moment. Once you’ve achieved it, it’s a thing of the past. But all the qualities you have learned stay with you. If running a marathon instead of a half marathon helps you become more disciplined and confident, the long-term benefits are great because you can apply these skills to other disciplines in your life, such as work or personal relationships.
A more ambitious goal will accelerate the rate at which you learn these qualities and help you become a more complete person. You may think this all sounds very nice, but setting a big goal is more likely to lead to failure. And nobody likes to fail. That’s true, but it doesn’t mean that failure doesn’t matter. It does matter. But there is something more dangerous than failure.
The Italian sculptor Michelangelo Buonarroti once said: “The greatest danger to the majority is not in aiming too high and failing, but in aiming too low and succeeding”.
When Kennedy announced his intention to put a man on the moon, it was such an ambitious goal that it was also a leap of faith. And sometimes that is what we need. To throw ourselves into an ambitious goal, knowing that failure is very likely, and without any certainty about the journey we have to take. And who knows what might happen.

A lot of people find writing difficult. I think so too. When I first started writing, there wasn’t a day that went by that I didn’t end up frustrated. When I tried to articulate an idea, I couldn’t find the words. Often I had no idea what I was writing about. It still happens.
When I was really frustrated and wanted to give up, I thought the main problem was that writing was complicated. My frustration was justified, I thought, and the only solution was to improve my writing skills.
But then I read something that changed my perspective.
Emotional control is key to mastery In his book An Astronaut’s Guide to Life on Earth, Chris Hadfield talks about how hard it is to become an astronaut. He says that you can be the most talented person in the world, but you won’t become an astronaut if you lack certain skills, such as “the ability to push yourself to the point of discomfort and beyond”.
If becoming an astronaut, one of the most complicated jobs there is, requires skills like hard work, what role can those skills play in writing? Can I be good at writing if I don’t know how to push myself to the point of discomfort or be disciplined?
In his book Mastery, Robert Greene explores what it takes to achieve mastery in any field, using the examples of Einstein, Da Vinci, Marie Curie and many others. And he explains something that I don’t think we pay enough attention to.
What separates masters from others is often something surprisingly simple. Whenever we learn a skill, we often feel frustrated; what we are learning seems beyond our capabilities. By giving in to these feelings, we unconsciously give up on ourselves before we really give up.
The only real impediment to mastery is yourself and your emotions - boredom, panic, frustration, insecurity. You cannot suppress such emotions; they are normal to the process and are experienced by everyone, including Masters. What you can do is have faith in the process.
When we face a difficult problem, our enemy is not only the problem itself, but also our attitude. And this is interesting because it is often we ourselves who make things more difficult.
Imagine you are trapped in a maze and you want to get out. You will try different ways and it is normal not to find the way out at first. When this happens you will feel frustration, panic and even fear. This is normal. But the important thing is how you react.
You can see your mistakes as a sign that you are unable to get out of the maze. If you let frustration and panic take over, it will be harder to get out of the maze.
Or you can look at your mistakes as something positive. You try to reason and realise that you haven’t reached the exit, but you’ve found a way that doesn’t work. Now you are closer to finding the exit because you know the maze better. You still feel difficult emotions, but you don’t let them cloud your judgement. You don’t want to give up, you want to keep trying.
What role does emotional control play in finding the solution? This is hard to quantify. It is clear that emotional control alone is not enough to get out of the maze. You need knowledge, but with poor emotional control, getting out of the maze is much more complicated.
Similarly, when we reach our limit, how do we know whether it is the difficulty of the problem, our attitude, or a combination of both? It is very difficult to know; it is a question only you can answer for yourself. But it is clear that the way you react to a problem determines to some extent its difficulty.
Writing is difficult. But when I encounter problems, if my attitude isn’t right, I make the situation worse. I make writing more difficult.
When frustration sets in, I can take it as a sign that I have no idea how to write, so I give up. Or I can see frustration as a sign that I’m doing something complex, because otherwise I wouldn’t be frustrated. And I can see that if I can keep going, I will improve as a writer.
The meaning you give to your emotions is up to you. You can make them your friend or your enemy.
And that is the key, because behind extraordinary achievements lies inhuman emotional control.
How the best athletes control their emotions Eliud Kipchoge is the greatest marathon runner of all time. Of the 21 marathons he has run, Kipchoge has won 18, including two Olympic gold medals. It takes more than exceptional fitness to achieve this feat. You also have to have exceptional emotional control. Others may run away from difficult situations like boredom or frustration, but athletes like Kipchoge can’t afford to do that. And the following story illustrates this.
After winning gold in the marathon at the Tokyo 2021 Olympic Games, Kipchoge and several other runners were waiting in a hall to collect their medals.
But organizational problems meant they had to wait for hours. Tired after the marathon, there was not much to do in the room. Bored, most of the runners did the usual thing: they looked for distractions. They took out their smartphones and spent their time surfing the internet or social media.
All except one. Kipchoge.
Kipchoge stood silently, waiting patiently for his medal. The rest of the runners escaped boredom, but not Kipchoge. As one of the runners in the room later joked, “Kipchoge is not human.
It’s impossible to win a marathon at such a high level and not feel incredible pain at some point during the race. Or doubt yourself when you know you are the greatest marathoner of all time and everyone is watching. Or feeling pressure. Or the weight of high expectations.
These are defining moments, and good emotional control is key to keeping them in check. After all, you can’t be emotionally strong and win 18 out of 21 marathons.
Novak Djokovic, the most decorated tennis player of all time, also knows the importance of emotions in performing at the highest level. He recently became the player with the most Grand Slams in history and reached 400 weeks at number one. Such consistency was unthinkable in a sport as demanding as tennis until he achieved it. He doesn’t just break records. He creates new ones.Asked in a recent interview about the secret to his mental toughness, Djokovic said:
Probably one of the biggest lessons I’ve learnt about mental toughness is that if you lose focus because things start to go wrong for you, that’s OK. Accept it and come back to the present moment. How you bounce back is the most important thing.
I think what separates you from other people is how long you stay in that negative emotional state. Because it’s almost impossible to stay in the present moment all the time. We’re always thinking about what’s going to happen, how I’m going to win or whatever. But the speed with which you recover from a loss of concentration and come back to the present is one of the most important ingredients of mental toughness.
It’s not about a spectacular backhand or a spectacular serve, it’s about the ability to come back to the present moment, to calm your mind and play your best.
Conclusion No matter who you are or what you do, there will always be someone you have to beat. It’s you. The enemy is not only outside, but also inside you.
Difficult emotions will always arise. They cannot be avoided. But what you can do is learn to deal with them. We are all likely to be limited more by a lack of emotional control than by the difficulty of the problem we face, so the ability to prevent your emotions from overwhelming or derailing you is one of the factors that can help you excel the most.
The enemy is both outside and within you. Control your emotions.

In the science fiction saga The Hitchhiker’s Guide to the Galaxy, a group of space explorers search for the answer to the meaning of life by creating a supercomputer. After seven million years of work, the supercomputer comes up with the answer: 42.
To everyone’s astonishment, the computer replies: “That’s definitely the answer. I think the problem, to be honest, is that you didn’t really know what the question was”.
The Hitchhiker’s Guide to the Galaxy was one of the books that had the greatest impact on Elon Musk as a child. It taught him that it was not about finding answers, but about asking the right questions. Years later, when Musk went on to found SpaceX, a company whose mission is to take humans to Mars and make life multi-planetary, he said one of his motivations was “expand the scope of consciousness to ask the questions about the answer, which is the universe”.
If making sure the questions are the right ones before rushing to find the answers has been the key to creating SpaceX, the most important space company today, perhaps there is something we can all learn from asking better questions. But it is not an easy skill.
We are good at finding answers. But not good at asking good questions.
At school, we were taught that the important thing was to find the right answer. Exams consisted of questions that students had to answer to the best of your ability. The better the answer, the higher the grade.
The question was never challenged. Nobody would sit an exam and say something like “this question is badly worded” or “there are more interesting questions that could be asked”. You just answered. Even if the question was stupid or badly worded, if you answered well, you got the maximum mark.
Because success at school was associated with getting good grades, we quickly learned to associate intelligence with the ability to answer questions well. And this works in school because it is a controlled environment. But in the real world, where there are many more degrees of freedom, it often doesn’t help much.
A good question can almost solve a problem The story goes that in the Middle Ages a Chinese military strategist was the guest of a European prince. During his stay, he had the opportunity to be the guest of honor at one of the many jousting tournaments. These tournaments were no mere pastime. They were often used to avoid further conflict and to decide the future marriage of heirs.
The wise Chinese strategist asked his princely friend how the competition worked. He explained the simple rule: each prince would send his three best champions to compete against each other: the team that won the most fights would be the winner.
The Chinese master meditated for a moment and then suggested to the prince: “Dear friend, allow me to give you a piece of advice: let your third champion fight his first champion, your first champion his second and your second champion his third. You will lose the first match, but win the other two.” And so it was.
When we focus on finding answers without challenging the question, we sometimes work inefficiently. The story of the warriors illustrates this perfectly. Up to that point, no European prince had ever thought of changing the order of his warriors. They just assumed that the best fought first. To win the battle, their question to answer is: how can I make my best warrior beat their best warrior? and so on.
But the Chinese warrior does things differently. Before focusing on finding an answer, he tries to understand and formulate the problem better. There are three clashes, and the one who wins two wins. There are no other restrictions. And he realizes that if you change the order in which you take out your warriors, you will gain a considerable advantage. Choose your worst warrior against his best and you will lose the first battle, but you will win the next two. And you will win.
The advantage of asking good questions Once the Chinese warrior asked the right question, the solution was almost self-evident. In a graduation speech, Steve Jobs said something like, “Imagine you were in a city and you could see it all from the 80th floor. While other people are trying to figure out how to get from point A to point B by reading these stupid maps, you can see it all in front of you. You can see it all. And you can make connections that seem obvious to you because you can see everything.”
There’s an idea from Albert Einstein that says: “If I had an hour to solve a problem, and my life depended on the solution, I would spend the first 55 minutes determining the appropriate question, because once I knew the right question, I could solve the problem in less than five minutes.
That’s the power of asking good questions; many problems become obvious and solve themselves.
Elon Musk was once asked what was one of the most common mistakes made by brilliant engineers. He said: “Trying to optimize a problem that shouldn’t exist in the first place”. If the problem isn’t right, it doesn’t matter how good you are at finding the answer. The search won’t get you very far.
Imagine that answering a question is like reaching the top of a huge mountain. Before you start climbing, you have to make sure that the mountain is the right one. Otherwise, you run the risk of getting to the top of the mountain and saying: Wait, what am I doing here? Before you answer a question, make sure it is the right one.
The ability to ask good questions will determine not only the difficulty of the problem, but also how far we can go. Arthur Schopenhauer once said: “Talent achieves the goal that no one else can achieve. Genius achieves the goal that no one else can see.”
Being good at finding answers is similar to hitting the target that no one else can hit. It is a good skill, and it will certainly help you go far. But if you’re really looking for genius, it’s not enough. If you focus only on finding answers, you will only be able to define problems defined by others.
By contrast, mastering the art of asking good questions will help you create something new. There are times when the greatest value lies not in exploring what we already know, but in discovering and exploiting what no one else can see. And for that, nothing beats a good question.

At the age of thirteen, Bruce Lee discovered his true passion: martial arts. He practiced every day, all the time. He was so talented, skilled, hard-working and driven. No one doubted he would be unstoppable. He devoted himself body and soul to the discipline. But there was a problem.
From time to time, Yip Man, his teacher, tried to teach him key ideas: “Never impose yourself on nature. It flows”, “never oppose any problem head on, but counter it by balancing with it.”
But Bruce did not understand these messages. Nor did they interest him. All the young Bruce Lee wanted was to practice, practice, practice. To punch, to move, to jump. Non-stop. The more the better. There was no time for philosophical ideas.
Yip Man was alarmed. Yes, his ideas were profound. But they hid the essence of the martial arts. Without mastering them, Bruce would not get very far. So he changed his strategy. He told Bruce Lee that for a week there would be no training. But he gave him a task: he had to reflect and try to understand his abstract teachings.
Bruce went ballistic. Asking him to rest was like telling a person not to breathe. Bruce, whose nickname was “Never Sit Still”, thought that missing a week of training would make him worse. Working hard, and not resting, is what would get him to the top.
At first Bruce resisted, but soon after he agreed. And what he learned next would change his life forever.
Agitated and angry, Bruce decided to take a boat and go paddling on a lake. After a while, he decided to lie down and reflect on Yip Man’s teachings. Finding no solution, he became so frustrated that he started punching the water with all his might. At that moment, he became paralyzed. A thought came to him. He had just understood the teachings of his master.
As Bruce Lee said in his essays:
Hadn’t this water illustrated to me the principle of gung fu? I hit it, but it did not suffer any damage.I struck it again with all my might, but it was not hurt. […] This water, the softest substance in the world, which could be contained in the smallest bottle, seemed only weak. In reality, it could penetrate the hardest substances in the world. That was it! Yip wanted it to be like the nature of water.
The idea about the nature of water would become a key element for Bruce Lee, both in the martial arts and in his philosophy of life. One of his most important lemmas is “Be Water, My Friend”.
Empty your mind, be formless. Shapeless, like water. If you put water into a cup, it becomes the cup. You put water into a bottle and it becomes the bottle. You put it in a teapot, it becomes the teapot. Now, water can flow or it can crash. Be water, my friend.
To take a step forward, maybe you need to take two steps backwards When we really like something it is very easy to become obsessed with it. We adopt an all-or-nothing mentality, forgetting that there are always nuances. Either I’m working directly towards my goal, or I’m wasting my time.
But it doesn’t have to be like that. Bruce Lee had his epiphany with water when he stopped his training and spent time doing nothing. Without that moment, Bruce Lee might never have become who he was.
There are times when it is necessary to take a step back in order to take two steps forward. If you are an artist, passive activities such as walking will enhance your creativity. Beethoven carried his scores with him on his walks. Nietzsche said, “Only ideas gained by walking are of any value”.
Procrastination can be productive. At the end of a day’s work writing a film script, Quentin Tarantino goes to his swimming pool and floats. This moment is crucial to his creativity, as it helps him to absorb the ideas he has worked on during the day and generate new ones to work on the next day.
Einstein played the violin when he got stuck solving a complicated physics problem. When Andrew Wiles got stuck trying to solve Fermat’s Theorem, he would go for walks to relax and let his subconscious mind work on the problem.
There is a very famous saying commonly attributed to Navy SEALs that refers to firing a weapon. “Slow is smooth. Smooth is fast.” Trying to go too fast can jam the mechanism, making it impossible to fire. But if you do things carefully and in a timely manner, everything will run smoothly and the gun will fire.
As the psychologist and researcher Amos Tversky said: the secret to doing good research is to always be a little underemployed. Years are wasted because you can’t waste hours.
Sometimes you have to take a step back to take two steps forward.
summary:
At the age of thirteen, Bruce Lee discovered his true passion: martial arts. He practiced every day, all the time. He was so talented, skilled, hard-working and driven. No one doubted he would be unstoppable. He devoted himself body and soul to the discipline. But there was a problem.
From time to time, Yip Man, his teacher, tried to teach him key ideas: “Never impose yourself on nature. It flows”, “never oppose any problem head on, but counter it by balancing with it.
title: Take a step back

In the 19th century, the British government faced a critical dilemma when it came to transporting prisoners to Australia. The prisoner survival rate was a worrying 40 per cent. In an effort to improve it, various government organizations and humanitarian groups proposed improvements. But after several attempts, the survival rate remained at 40 per cent.
The situation did not improve until Edwin Chadwick, a visionary economist, decided to change the focus of the problem. He realized that the real drawback was not the conditions of the voyage, but the behavior of the crew. At the time, the captains were paid for each prisoner shipped to England. In other words, the captains were rewarded before doing their real job: transporting the prisoners to Australia. As a result, they didn’t really have an interest in ensuring that the prisoners were in good health at the time of their arrival in Australia.
Edwin Chadwick, who was a good economist, knew that incentives were key to influencing mass behavior. So he proposed a new strategy: to pay the captains for every prisoner who arrived safely in Australia.
This simple adjustment produced extraordinary results: the survival rate rose to over 98%.
The power of incentives. As Morgan House says in his book Same As Ever, “incentives are the most powerful force in the world”. The problem is that, as well as having a positive effect, as in the case of prisoner transport, they can also have the opposite effect. And the role of space regulators is a clear example of this.
SpaceX is an American company whose mission is to colonize Mars and transform humanity into a multi-planetary species. To achieve such an ambitious goal, it is necessary to act in a different way than the old companies in the industry are used to. For example, you have to challenge conventional wisdom. Often you have to fight to change certain rules because they don’t encourage innovation and they’re stupid.
And that is exactly what is happening on many occasions between SpaceX and the Federal Aviation Administration (FAA), the organization responsible for aviation safety and regulation in the US.
In a meeting with SpaceX to discuss some routine approvals of a launch, a regulator pointed out some of the rules that SpaceX was in violation of. Elon Musk challenged the regulator’s reasoning, saying that some of the rules needed to be changed because they didn’t encourage the innovation needed to get to Mars. And then he claimed:
There is a fundamental problem with regulators. If a regulator agrees to change a rule and something bad happens, they can easily lose their career. Whereas if they change a rule and something good happens, they don’t even get a reward. So it’s very asymmetric. So it’s very easy to understand why regulators are reluctant to change the rules. It’s because there is a big punishment on one side and no reward on the other. How would a rational person behave in such a scenario?
Charlie Munger, one of the greatest investors in history, believed that “never, ever think about anything else when you should be thinking about the power of incentives”.
In other words, regulators do not have the right incentives. As Morgan Housel once said, being rational is not the same as being reasonable. Regulators are rational because they behave according to the incentives they have, but they are not rational if what you really want is innovation and technological progress. There is a quote from Upton Sinclair that says: “It is very difficult for a man to understand something when his salary depends on his not understanding it”.
This problem is not restricted to regulators. Many Fortune 500 CEOs do not pursue innovation because their compensation is tied to short-term quarterly results, and innovation is a long-term bet. It’s not that they don’t have the ability to innovate, it’s that they don’t have the will because they don’t have the motivation.
In the book The 48 Laws of Power, author Robert Greene talks about the importance of interest in influencing others. He tells the story of how Chinese culture was on the brink of destruction in the mid 12th century.
When Genghis Khan, the leader of the Mongol Empire, invaded China, he found a country lacking in the resources he considered valuable. Known for his zeal for destruction, Genghis Khan decided it would be best to raze all Chinese cities to the ground. This would mean the destruction of two thousand years of Chinese culture.
But a trusted advisor to Genghis Khan, who appreciated the beauty of Chinese culture, convinced him that he would reap riches from the place if, instead of destroying it, he simply taxed everyone who lived there. Khan saw the wisdom in this and listened to his advisor.
Benjamin Franklin once said, “If you want to persuade, appeal to interest, not reason”.

Nelson Mandela spent his life fighting to overthrow apartheid and bring democracy to South Africa, where all South Africans, regardless of their social status or color, would be allowed to vote.
He was imprisoned for 27 years. He endured hard labor, severe isolation and very basic living conditions. He had to overcome internal conflicts within his political movement, whose members had doubts about the best course of action for the overthrow of apartheid. He also needed to fight the racism and colonialism that had been formed for centuries But in the end he achieved his goal. Mandela was released from prison in 1990 and played a key role in the transition to democracy. In 1994, he became the first democratically elected president in South Africa’s history.
Whether it was his visionary belief in a democratic South Africa, his iron discipline to achieve his goal, or his empathy to connect with those who thought differently from him, Mandela is considered a great leader.
So you might think that in order to be a leader, or simply a person of value, it is necessary to be a great achiever. But it doesn’t have to be that way.
On Robben Island prison, prisoners were assigned daily chores. One of the most unpleasant was to clean their chamber pot with their own excrement. All the prisoners hated it. Once, one of Mandela’s companions, Daniels, fell ill for a short time. Without the strength to even get out of bed, he decided to postpone cleaning his chamber pot. Mandela cared for all his comrades. He knew his friend was unwell. Daniels recalls that Mandela came to his cell, asked how he was and then set about cleaning his comrade’s chamber pot on his own initiative. Daniels was amazed.
That is what leadership is about. It is not just about being the visible face of a historic political movement or achieving great feats. Small actions can make a big difference.
And that’s something anyone can learn.
You can be one of three ways Chris Hadfield, a Canadian astronaut and current commander of the International Space Station, believes that everyone in a new environment can fall into one of three categories:
As -1: actively disruptive, someone who causes problems. As 0: their impact is neutral and does not tip the balance one way or the other. As +1: someone who actively adds value.
In the case of astronauts, you might think that being competent, intelligent and a problem solver is enough to be categorized as a +1. But being an astronaut also requires teamwork; the most important missions on the ISS always require a crew of astronauts. Those with an individualistic view may think that skills such as teamwork are useless in such cases, but nothing could be further from the truth. As he recalls of the astronaut selection process:
“A chief astronaut used to call the reception of the clinic where the applicants were sent for medical tests to find out which ones treated the staff well and which ones didn’t. […] A person with a superiority complex could unwittingly, right there in the waiting room, ruin his chances of ever going into space.”
A person with a superiority complex could unwittingly ruin his chances of ever going into space. Everything counts. If you have the wrong idea of what it means to add value, you may never get the chance to do it.
That’s why Hadfield believes that one of the best ways to add value is to start by aiming to be a zero, that is, to aspire to have a neutral impact.
Aim to be a zero, at least in the beginning. On one of his first space missions, Hadfield, eager to learn as much as possible, decided to observe the behavior of the most experienced astronaut on the mission. As he recounts in his book An Astronaut’s Guide to Life on Earth, “I was observing the most experienced astronaut in our crew […] and I noticed that he would come into the office an hour early and quietly go through our commander’s inbox, taking care of all the administrative details himself so that the commander could concentrate on the important things”.
Common sense tells us that it should be the other way round. The most experienced should do the most important tasks, leaving the less attractive ones to the newcomers. Everyone wants to be a +1. And nobody wants to be a -1. But it is best to aim to be a zero, at least in the beginning.
Aiming to be neutral may be one of the best ways to become someone who adds value. It may sound counterintuitive, but sometimes it makes all the difference. Doing the dirty work, like Mandela with the chamber pot or the astronaut checking the inbox, may not seem like a useful task, but it really is if it helps others do their best.
Warren Buffet and Charlie Munger are considered two of the greatest investors of all time. When asked what made them so good, Charlie Munger said: “It’s remarkable how much long-term advantage people like us have gained by trying not to be stupid, rather than trying to be very smart.”
When you enter a new environment, such as a new job, you always want to add value. But, as we have seen throughout this article, you have to be careful. If you are desperate to stand out, you are more likely to make more mistakes. As Hadfield says: “The ideal entry is not to sail in and immediately make your presence known. It is to enter without causing a domino effect. The best way to contribute to a new environment is not to try to show how wonderful you are. It is to try to have a neutral impact, to observe and learn from those who are already there, and to help with the dirty work whenever possible.”
Rather than actively seeking to add value, seek to do no harm. To paraphrase Charlie Munger, seeking brilliance is difficult, but avoiding stupidity is easier. Avoiding stupidity is analogous to striving to become someone with a neutral impact. If you do that, sooner or later you will be the kind of person who adds value.
summary:
Nelson Mandela spent his life fighting to overthrow apartheid and bring democracy to South Africa, where all South Africans, regardless of their social status or color, would be allowed to vote.
He was imprisoned for 27 years. He endured hard labor, severe isolation and very basic living conditions. He had to overcome internal conflicts within his political movement, whose members had doubts about the best course of action for the overthrow of apartheid.
title: Aim to be a zero

content:
Hundreds of millions of people were watching television. It has been an intense decade of relentless work, without rest. Expectation was at an all-time high. Too much was at stake. It was 20 July 1969, and two American astronauts were about to become the first humans to set foot on the moon.
Eight years earlier, President Kennedy had inspired an entire nation by announcing his goal of putting a man on the moon before the end of the decade. That same day, by leaving his foot mark on the lunar surface, Neil Armstrong would in turn inspire a whole generation of young people.
One of those children was Chris Hadfield. At just nine years old, watching Neil Armstrong on the moon on television, he decided he wanted to be an astronaut. Just another child, one might think, among all those who wished to become astronauts that day.
The only thing is that 43 years later, Chris Hadfield was about to make his third space trip, and was also appointed head commander of the International Space Station.
What would an astronaut do? Having watched on television that evening how man landed on the moon, Hadfield decided to become an astronaut. The problem was that, as aerospace interest was relatively new, there was no pre-established path to becoming an astronaut. NASA had been in existence for barely a decade. Hadfield was Canadian, and Canada didn’t even have a space agency then.
Most people would have given up before they started. But not Hadfield. What Hadfield decided to do was quite remarkable for a nine-year-old boy. As he recounts in his book An Astronaut’s Guide to Life on Earth, “I had only one choice. I had to imagine what an astronaut would do if he were nine years old, and then do exactly the same. Would he eat vegetables or french fries? Would he sleep late or get up early to read a book?”
At first glance, one might think that there is no direct relationship between eating vegetables or getting up early to read a book and being an astronaut. And that is true. But the benefit of the questions Hadfield asked himself was not about eating healthier or reading more books.
What was really important in that question was the kind of person he was becoming.
Who are you becoming Becoming an astronaut is a very difficult goal. It requires skills very few people have. There are hundreds of thousands of candidates, but only a few spots. And it also doesn’t help that in any goal we pursue, there are always factors beyond your control such as luck or risk.
You may not be born at the right time. Or in the right country. Maybe on one of the space programme’s journeys there is an explosion that kills the entire crew, as happened with Challenger, and spaceflight would be put on hold for years pending review. Or there could be a war, and space travel would be put on the back burner. Or perhaps the astronaut candidate could be on the verge of becoming an astronaut but suffer an illness that prevents him from travelling into space (Hadfield was very close to experiencing this).
I don’t mean to imply that luck is all that matters. How skilled and competent you are plays an important role. If you are unlucky you may not be an astronaut, but if you have no skill then you will never be an astronaut.
When Hadfield wondered whether to go to bed late or get up early to read a book, he was increasing his chances of being an astronaut. He was becoming the kind of person who is disciplined and knows how to work hard to achieve his goals. He was practising perseverance and self-control. He was aware that being an astronaut was complicated, but every time he asked himself that question and answered it, it was as if he was saying to himself: I’m not giving up.
No one knows what the future will bring. But in a way your choices determine what you will get out of life. Imagine a future of endless possibilities. You want to run a marathon? You’re less likely to run a marathon if you don’t exercise or eat healthy. Do you know where you want to work? No, but if you don’t spend time learning, you are less likely to get a job you like.
We often don’t realize that we are constantly changing. Heraclitus once said: “No man can cross the same river twice, because neither the man nor the water will be the same”.
Every decision we make influences, even if only remotely, the kind of person we are becoming. That is why the questions Hadfield asked himself are so important. His chances of becoming an astronaut were negligible, almost zero, but if he didn’t ask himself that question and act on it, his chances would be zero. His actions opened up new avenues of possibility.
Step by step As James Clear says in his book Atomic Habits, “Every action you take is a vote for the kind of person you want to become”.
If the goal you are pursuing is ambitious, it is very likely that sooner or later you will feel overwhelmed. When that happens, remember E.L. Doctorow’s insight: “Writing a novel is like driving a car at night. You can only see as far as the headlights can reach, but then you can make the whole trip.”
You don’t need to visualise the whole road to start walking. You just need to see a little further ahead. Like when Hadfield was nine years old and wondered what an astronaut would do.
If your goal is to become a healthier person but you don’t know what to do, you can do like Hadfield and ask yourself: Would an athlete go for a run or lie on the couch?, would an athlete eat junk food or healthy food? And once you have the answer, act. You don’t just lie on the couch, you go for a run. Even if it’s just a few meters.
If your goal is to become a writer but you don’t know how to fight procrastination, you can ask yourself: Would a writer let go of that emotion or would he or she start writing anyway? And once you have the answer, you act. You don’t give up, you start writing. Even if it’s just a few words.
It’s like driving a car at night. You can only see as far as the headlights reach, but you can make the whole journey.
One might think that such small actions are not enough to achieve big results. True, but only if you only look at the short term. A day or even a couple of weeks is not enough time to make a difference, but several months and years will make a big difference. Small actions over a long period of time can lead to extraordinary results. Small actions can help you achieve big goals and, in the process, have the ability to change the kind of person you become.

This article is about the story of The Choice of Hercules’, which is a metaphor for the ability we all have to make choices and the consequences of those choices. The version of The Choice of Hercules presented here is an excerpt from Donald Robertson’s book How to Think Like a Roman Emperor.
One day, as a young man, Hercules was walking along an unfamiliar path when he came upon a fork in the road, where he sat down and began contemplating his future. Unsure which direction to take, he found himself suddenly confronted by two mysterious goddesses.
The first appeared as a beautiful and alluring woman dressed in fine clothing. She was called Kakia, although she (falsely) claimed that her friends called her Eudaimonia, meaning happiness and fulfillment. She barged before her companion and earnestly pleaded with Hercules to follow her path. It led, she promised, to the easiest and most pleasant way of life, a shortcut to true happiness. She told him that he could live like a king, avoiding hardship and enjoying luxury beyond most men’s wildest dreams, all delivered to him through the labor of others.
After listening to her for a while, Hercules was approached by the second goddess, Arete, a less boastful and more modest woman who shone with natural beauty. To his surprise, she wore a grave expression. She warned him that her path led in a very different direction: it would be long, challenging, and require much hard work. Speaking plainly, she told Hercules that he would suffer. He would be doomed to walk the earth in rags, reviled and persecuted by his enemies.
“Nothing that is really good and admirable,” cautioned Arete, “is granted by the gods to men without some effort and application.” Hercules would be called upon to exercise wisdom and justice and to face mounting adversity with bravery and self-discipline.
Overcoming extraordinary obstacles through courageous and honorable deeds, the goddess said, was the only true path to fulfillment in life. Hercules famously chose the heroic path of Arete, or “Virtue,” and was not seduced by Kakia, or “Vice.”
When you need to make a decision, think about whether you’ll choose the easy path or the difficult path.

SPOILER ALERT: This blogpost is based on the book Lessons In Chemistry and contains spoilers.
Elizabeth Zott hated being in class, sitting at a desk listening to monotonous teachers talking about boring subjects. It wasn’t that she didn’t enjoy learning. She loved it. But all the learning there was based on memorisation, and Elizabeth liked creativity. Elizabeth also disliked her classmates who did not share her hobbies. And all this made her suffer. A lot. She was a ten-year-old girl and everything was supposed to be fun. But it wasn’t. She hated school, had no friends and never felt like she fit in.
The nightmare didn’t end when school ended and she came home. Her parents, especially her father, were not kind to Elizabeth. But there was always a light at the end of the tunnel: her older brother John. John was the opposite of what she didn’t like about her life. John was always there, always kind and protective, encouraging Elizabeth to question things and learn for herself.
Their relationship was amazing and grew stronger as they spent more time together. Elizabeth felt that everything could be terrible, but with John by her side, things would somehow work out. And then everything changed.
Elizabeth’s father was extremely intolerant of people who were different from him, and when he found out that his son John was gay, he harassed him. He thought it was a disgrace to have a gay son and decided to make his life impossible. Since then John has felt trapped, as if the day had come when he decided it was time to end it all. He committed suicide. When Elizabeth found out, she was alone and devastated. She felt hopeless, convinced there was nothing she could do to improve her life, and all she could see was darkness.
A few years later, when she was about to start university, she realised that she liked science because it gave her certainty. Specifically, chemistry. Atoms and chemical reactions were easier to understand than people. But it was the 1950s and women were not considered good enough. Women were mostly housewives and secretaries, not scientists, engineers or pilots.
She completed her undergraduate and master’s degrees with honours and decided to do a Ph.D. But soon after she started, her tutor tried to sexually abuse her, and because the professor was very powerful and women were treated unfairly, there was not even a trial. Elizabeth was forced to leave her university and drop out of her PhD. She looked for other PhD programmes but found none. The only way she could do science was to join an institute that offered an assistantship called Hastings, where she would work in a lab with scientists.
Conditions were far from ideal. She was not treated well at her new job and had to fight for everything, but at least people let her work on science, her passion. One day, while eating lunch in the cafeteria, she met Calvin Harris, one of the world’s most celebrated scientists. They quickly became friends. Harris, who also had a terrible childhood, was intelligent and kind. He was always supportive of Elizabeth, as was her older brother John. They spent a lot of time together, sharing many ideas and working together on research projects. It was the first time in a long time that she felt deeply understood. They quickly fell in love. She was happy. But one day everything changed.
Harris died in an accident, leaving her alone and devastated. Hastings stripped Harris of everything connected with him, including his lab team and funding. And because Elizabeth was dependent on Harris, she was fired. Elizabeth tried unsuccessfully to find another job, and as a result she ran out of money. She discovered she was pregnant and would soon be a single mother. Things were looking bleak, but giving up was not in Elizabeth’s nature. Her daughter, Mad, and her love of chemistry would save her. And also cooking, which had always interested her because she believed it was the same as chemistry. With no job and a lot of free time, she did what different and innovative people do: combine unrelated ideas in unexpected and never-before-seen ways, resulting in original creations. Using unexplored techniques together with her in-depth knowledge of chemistry, she created new recipes that had never been seen before.
After catching the eye of a friend who worked as a television director, Elizabeth was offered to host a cooking show: Dinner at Six. She would cook one meal a day and discuss the importance of healthy eating with potentially millions of people watching. Elizabeth didn’t like the idea, but she needed the money, so she accepted. When she was at school, no one knew her. Now things were different. At first the show did not do well and was on the verge of being cancelled. But people began to love the originality of Elizabeth, whose recipes and analogies between chemistry and cooking blew the audience away.
Against all odds, the show became a national success and Elizabeth was deeply admired. But after several successful years, Elizabeth decided to quit the show because she never wanted to be a national TV star. All she wanted was to do science, her true passion. Elizabeth occasionally sent encouraging messages to the audience, and on the last day of the show she sent a special one:
“Whenever you start doubting yourself or feeling afraid, just remember. Courage is the root of change, and change is what we’re chemically designed to do. So when you wake up tomorrow, make this pledge. No more holding yourself back. No more subscribing to other’s opinions of what you can and cannot achieve. And no more allowing anyone to pigeonhole you into useless categories of sex, race, economic status, and religion. Do not allow your talents to lie dormant, ladies. Design your own future. When you go home today, ask yourself what you will change. And then get started.”
When we feel inspired by someone, it is not just because of what they do or how they do it. It’s also because of why they do it. Elizabeth was excellent at cooking and used innovative techniques, but the most important thing was the principles and values she embodied. She didn’t accept the status quo, rejecting and challenging all preconceived notions about what women could do. Elizabeth believed that there is hidden potential inside every person, and she used cooking to help people discover how to unleash it. Elizabeth experienced many setbacks throughout her life but didn’t get stuck in the past. That’s what all her audience saw, making Elizabeth so admired. She knew it was not what happens to you that matters but your reaction to these experiences. That means the key is your willingness to embrace and adopt change and get started, no matter what.
“Design your own future. When you go home today, ask yourself what you will change. And then get started.” ~ Elizabett Zoth, Lessons in Chemistry.

This is a excerpt from the graduation speech that John Roberts, Chief Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States, delivered at his son’s high school in Cardigan on 3 June 2017:
From time to time in the years to come, I hope you will be treated unfairly, so that you will come to know the value of justice.
I hope that you will suffer betrayal because that will teach you the importance of loyalty.
Sorry to say, but I hope you will be lonely from time to time so that you don’t take friends for granted.
I wish you bad luck, again, from time to time so that you will be conscious of the role of chance in life and understand that your success is not completely deserved and that the failure of others is not completely deserved either.
And when you lose, as you will from time to time, I hope every now and then, your opponent will gloat over your failure. It is a way for you to understand the importance of sportsmanship.
I hope you’ll be ignored so you know the importance of listening to others, and I hope you will have just enough pain to learn compassion.
Whether I wish these things or not, they’re going to happen. And whether you benefit from them or not will depend upon your ability to see the message in your misfortunes.

content:
Edith and her sister Magda achieved what seemed impossible: to get out of Auschwitz alive. They survived the most lethal Nazi concentration and extermination camp, where nearly one million people died. But they were not free. Not yet. When Nazi Germany was on the verge of defeat, the SS organized “death marches”, forced evacuations of concentration camps over long distances under guard and extremely harsh conditions.
Edith and Magda were moved to other concentration camps like Mauthausen, where prisoners were made to hack and carry granite to construct Hitler’s desired new capital for Germany. Mauthausen was also known for the Stairs of Death, where prisoners were forced to climb 186 with 110-pound granite blocks on their backs. Here, Edith came very close to death.
After Mauthausen came another concentration camp, Gunskirchen. It was less fearsome than Auschwitz or Mauthausen because it was not an extermination camp, and there were no crematoria or Stairs of Death, but prisoners there were on the brink of collapse. The many years of war, the inhuman conditions under which they were held in the concentration camps, and the brutality of the death marches began to take its toll. It was just too much. They were almost living corpses, and it was just a matter of time before they would die.
In Gunskirchen, things started to get very ugly for Edith. She couldn’t do it anymore. Knowing that the end was near, she lay down on one of the many piles of corpses and waited for the end. But then something remarkable happened.
The Americans liberated the camp, and a soldier, almost by chance, found Edith half-dead among the pile of corpses. Edith was rescued and taken safely along with the rest of the survivors. The moment Edith had been waiting for since she entered Auschwitz almost one year ago had come. Freedom. She was free. And on top of that, her sister Magda also survived! Both were free.
However, their situation was far from ideal. When Edith and her sister were liberated, almost everyone they knew and loved had died. Both were starving and severely malnourished. Edith later discovered that, due to physical abuse, her back was broken. She had tiffus, pneumonia, and pleuritis. The shock had been so great that she even had to relearn how to write and read. Only seventeen years old, she and her sister had lived through one of the greatest atrocities in human history. Edith was free, but healing would take much longer.
And now what? In a recent podcast interview, Edith was asked about Auschwitz. She said, “Auschwitz was an opportunity for an opportunity. An opportunity to discover the power within me, that no Nazi could ever take away from me.”
That’s quite profound. Part of the admiration that I feel for Edith comes from the fact that she went from experiencing such terrible things to seeing Auschwitz, almost 80 years later, as an opportunity to improve as a human being. I want to understand what it takes to get to that level of wisdom, and that’s why I recently wrote about Edith’s insights about the power of choice and the difference between victimhood and victimization. In this blog post, I will discuss one idea critical to understanding Edith’s healing.
Survivors don’t have time to ask, Why me? For survivors, the only relevant question is What now?
It doesn’t matter if you are a survivor; this question affects you because it is about the difference between living stuck in the past or focusing on the present and future. This distinction is crucial because it will define the type of person you become and what you get out of life.
As Edith says in her book The Gift, “We ask ‘Why?’ over and over, believing that if we could figure out the reason, the pain would lessen. Why did I get cancer? Why did I lose my job? Why did my partner have an affair? We search for answers, for understanding, as if there’s a logical reason to explain why things happened the way they did. But when we ask why, we’re stuck searching for someone or something to blame—including ourselves.”
We all have experienced at some point something that sucks, and we all have regrets and could name a few things we would do differently today. Sometimes, it’s gone too far, and we feel like we need time to process these negative experiences, and that’s fine. But don’t take too much time because being stuck in the past wishing things to be different doesn’t help. There is a Buddhist parable that goes as follows:
Suppose a man is struck by a poisoned arrow and the doctor wishes to take out the arrow immediately. Suppose the man does not want the arrow removed until he knows who shot it, his age, his parents, and why he shot it. What would happen? If he were to wait until all these questions had been answered, the man might die first.
That’s what happens when we get stuck in the past asking, “Why me?”. This short story perfectly illustrates the consequences of being stuck in the past and how pointless it is to care for things that don’t matter.
Think again about Edith. With all she had to go through, she could have let hate or fear consume her, or she could have been stuck in the past, blaming Hitler for all the problems in her life. And it would be understandable, but she did the opposite: she realized the past can’t be changed and that sometimes there is only one thing you can do: focus on the present moment and look ahead.
As she says in her book The Gift, “When I ask, ‘What now?’ instead of ‘Why me?’ I stop focusing on why this bad thing happened—or is happening—and start paying attention to what I can do with my experience.”
That’s one of the reasons why she’s so inspiring, and I believe Edith is the standard for how anyone should recover from hardship. Pause for a moment and reflect on how far you could get if you started paying attention to the present moment instead of wasting time and energy on the past. If instead of trying to change what can’t be changed, you focus on what can be done to improve the situation at hand. I would say you could achieve things you now consider impossible.
Do you know Amelia Earhart? She had the dream of becoming the first women aviator. But being a woman in the 1920s was not easy, especially if you wanted to become an aviator. She had to overcome gender stereotypes, financial constraints, and even several flying accidents. She was mocked, denied, and underestimated.
But in 1932, after years of defying the odds, Amelia Earhart became the first woman to fly solo across the Atlantic Ocean. This was an incredible feat, accomplished only by a select group of people. She went on to broke different world records, becoming a historical figure in aviation. And more importantly, Amelia Earhart became an iconic figure for her determination and courage to push boundaries, her fight for women’s rights and her contributions to humanitarian efforts.
But what would Amelia have achieved if she had only focused on complaining about the unfair situation for women at that time? What if she had accepted the roles imposed by society and assumed that women could never fly? What if she had doubted herself?
She wouldn’t have achieved what she did and wouldn’t be Amelia Earhart. Imagine how mentally strong a person must be to do what she did. You can’t be normal and achieve what she did. When Amelia had to overcome challenges, what do you think she was most likely to say to herself: “Why me?” or “What now?” I think the answer is clear.
On the side of her plane Amelia Earhart painted the words, “Always move with your stick forward.” That’s it. Don’t ask why me. Don’t get stuck in the past. Ask what now. Always move with your stick forward.

Edith and her sister Magda achieved what seemed impossible: to get out of Auschwitz alive. They survived the most lethal Nazi concentration and extermination camp, where nearly one million people died. But they were not free. Not yet. When Nazi Germany was on the verge of defeat, the SS organized “death marches”, forced evacuations of concentration camps over long distances under guard and extremely harsh conditions.
Edith and Magda were moved to other concentration camps like Mauthausen, where prisoners were made to hack and carry granite to construct Hitler’s desired new capital for Germany.
title: Edith Eger (IV): And now what?

content:
Right after arriving at Auschwitz, Edith and her mother and sister were waiting in the selection line. They didn’t know it, but this would be their last moment together. While Edith and her sister Magda were sent to the left, their mother was sent to the right.
When Edith, just sixteen, entered the camp and asked where her mother was, one of the women dressed in striped dresses pointed to the smoke rising up from one of the chimneys in the distance. “Your mother is burning there,” she said. “You better start talking about her in the past tense.”
When the Nazi concentration camps were liberated, Edith was found under a pile of dead bodies. Although she survived, almost everyone she knew and loved had been killed. That really hit me, and even more because when she experienced that, and I read her book, we were about the same age. It made me reflect a lot on everything that I had.
I had never been very grateful. As a driven person, I always focused on what I didn’t have. Forget anything that means slowing down, I thought, because it’s an obstacle to getting more done. I never liked gratitude. I believed that being healthy or having family and friends were things I was supposed to have, as if they belonged to me. I was wrong.
What happened to Edith opened my eyes to the fact that everything you have could disappear at any moment. I realized I took many things for granted, and I felt regret. What if I lost a loved one, or became terribly ill? Appreciating something only after losing it is terrible, and I felt shame. I needed to learn to appreciate what I had, so I became interested in developing a gratitude practice.
Practicing gratitude is an ongoing process that requires daily work, but it is worth it. Shortly after arriving at Auschwitz, Edith understood, for the first time in her life, that she had a choice: to pay attention to what she lost or to pay attention to what she still had. Gratitude is also a choice, and I decided to practice gratitude every day. After several years, here’s what I learned.
Gratitude has improved my interpersonal relationships, especially with family and friends. That you have them shouldn’t be considered as something ordinary, but rather exceptional. Feeling grateful has motivated me to treat them with love and kindness and to try to help them when needed. It doesn’t have to be something extraordinary; small details are enough to make a difference. Gratitude has also made spending time with my loved ones, especially family, much more enjoyable and meaningful. And this is priceless.
It has also changed my relationship with myself. There are several ways to practice gratitude; one is to visualize losing what you have. I like memento mori, an ancient practice of reflecting on your mortality. It sounds scary, but I believe awareness of death can improve your life.
For example, now I’m more conscious that my time is limited, so I treat it as a gift. Once you realize how valuable time is, not wasting it becomes easier. Another consequence of memento mori is that I live more with a sense of urgency. Reflecting on your mortality also helps you to distinguish between what is important and not, and living a more fulfilling life is easier when you can focus on what truly matters. And finally, because you always have in mind that your life will end one day, you are more likely to live with more meaning and purpose. As Confucius said, “Every man has two lives, and the second starts when he realizes he has just one.”
I like to see my life as a candle that could go out at any moment. I carefully hold it in my hands. It’s fragile. And I look at it with amazement. Gratitude has shown me it’s a gift. After all, being alive is truly a miracle. One day, the candle will go out, but until then, I want its flame to shine as brightly as possible.
